metadata.title: Catalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) by nano-Fe2O3 activated peroxymonosulfate: Influential factors and mechanism determination

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Chemosphere
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/chemosphere
Catalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) by nano-Fe2O3 activated peroxymonosulfate: Influential factors and mechanism determination
Nematollah Jaafarzadeh a, b, Farshid Ghanbari a, b, *, Mehdi Ahmadi a, b
a Environmental Technologies Research Center, Ahvaz Jundishapur University of Medical Sciences, Ahvaz, Iran b Department of Environmental Health Engineering, School of Public Health, Ahvaz Jundishapur University of Medical Sciences, Ahvaz, Iran
h i g h l i g h t s
* Corresponding author. Department of Environme E-mail address: Ghanbari.env@gmail.com (F. Ghan
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.chemosphere.2016.11.038 0045-6535/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Hematite nanoparticles (HNPs) were synthesized to activate peroxymonosulfate (PMS). The HNPs/PMS system could effectively degrade dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D). The effects of Cl , NO3 , and HPO42 were assessed on PMS/HNPs performance. The presence of UV improved performance of the PMS/HNPs system significantly. The results showed that sulfate radical is the major agent of 2,4-D degradation.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 24 July 2016 Received in revised form 5 November 2016 Accepted 7 November 2016
Handling Editor: W Mitch
Keywords: Peroxymonosulfate 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid Hematite Sulfate radical Photocatalysis
a b s t r a c t
2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) is one of the most applicable herbicides in the world. Therefore, its residue in aquatic environment threatens the human health and ecosystems. In this study, Fe2O3 (hematite) nanoparticles (HNPs) were synthesized, and the characteristics of the obtained HNPs were determined using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), BrunauereEmmetteTeller (BET) technique, and particle size analyzer (PSA). The catalytic activity of HNPs was evaluated for the activation of peroxymonosulfate (PMS) for the degradation of 2,4-D. The effects of the operating parameters were studied for the PMS/ HNPs system. The results showed that the acidic condition provided higher efficiency, while overdosing of PMS had a scavenging effect. The PMS/HNPs showed high efficiency in comparison with the homogeneous forms of iron (Fe2þ and Fe3þ). Reusability of HNPs was studied in five consequent usages. The presence of the anions (chloride, nitrate, and hydrogen phosphate) reduced the 2,4-D degradation. Moreover, the catalytic activity of HNPs was also investigated in the presence of other oxidants. UV irradiation increased the function of PMS/HNPs and its mechanism was described. The order of 2,4-D removal for the oxidants was PMS > persulfate > H2O2 > percarbonate. A total of 29.7% of 2,4-D chlorine content was released during the destruction of 2,4-D. The quenching study showed that sulfate radical was the major agent in the degradation of 2,4-D.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
ntal Health Engineering, School of Public Health, Ahvaz Jundishapur University of Medical Sciences, Ahvaz, Iran. bari).

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The use of chemicals for increasing agricultural yield has been increased. In this process, the herbicides play a key role in controlling the weeds, which are the major inhibitors of crop growth. 2,4- Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) is a conventional herbicide that has been widely used in agricultural farms to control the weeds (Tang et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2009). 2,4-D is well known as a versatile herbicide that has been applied in various processes. Moreover, low cost and good performance have increased the 2,4-D application worldwide. Over 600 commercial types of 2,4-D are produced in market for the control of weeds (Matviishyn et al., 2014; Taktak et al., 2015). The extensive application of 2,4-D and its high solubility cause contamination of receivingwaters. The presence of this herbicide has been frequently reported in drainagewater and groundwater in high concentration. 2,4-D is a toxic chemical that can damage human organs such as the liver and kidney (Lemus et al., 2008). In addition, it has been reported that 2,4-D can be carcinogenic formammals. It is also well known as an endocrine disruptor (Seck et al., 2012). Hence, various methods have been developed for removing the herbicide from the aquatic environment. Its stability and toxicity have caused increased use of advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) for its degradation (Kamble et al., 2004). Advanced oxidation processes often apply a chemical oxidant for generating reactive radicals to destruct the organic compounds. Hydroxyl radical (HO ), a powerful oxidant (E0 ¼ 2.7 V), is the main oxidative agent in AOPs. There are several techniques used for generating the hydroxyl radical, including chemical, photochemical, sonochemical, and electrochemical processes (Asghar et al., 2015;Mahamuni and Adewuyi, 2010). Presently, increasing attention has beenpaid to the generation of sulfate radical (SO4 ) for degrading the environmental pollutants. The sulfate radical is a powerful oxidant with E0 ¼ 2.5e3.1 V, which is generated by the activation of persulfate or peroxymonosulfate (PMS) anions (Jaafarzadeh et al., 2016). Compared to persulfate, PMS is easily activated by the transition metals because of its unsymmetrical structure. Peroxymonosulfate is a benign substance, and it can be activated by different methods to produce the sulfate radicals (Ghanbari and Moradi, 2017; Guan et al., 2013). These methods include the use of transition metals (Anipsitakis and Dionysiou, 2003), ultraviolet (Jaafarzadeh et al., 2015), ultrasound (Su et al., 2012), heat (Yang et al., 2010), and carbon-based catalyst (Ghanbari et al., 2016). Transition metals such as Co, Fe, Cu and Mn have been widely applied as the activator agents for PMS.
Mnþ þ HSO 5 / Mðnþ1Þþ þ SO 4 þ OH (1)
Iron is a nontoxic, safe, and benign element and is available at low cost. Residuals of iron in homogeneous forms (Fe2þ or Fe3þ) should be separated from the solution that requires further processing. The heterogeneous nanoscale catalysts successfully overcome this limitation. Moreover, the heterogeneous catalyst can maintain its activity after repeated use, which is a significant advantage compared to the homogeneous form (Zhu et al., 2013). The hematite (Fe2O3) or iron oxide (III) has been widely used in photocatalysis and Fenton-based processes as the catalyst (Guo et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2016; Mishra and Chun, 2015). It exhibits high ability in decomposing hydrogen peroxide to generate hydroxyl radical. In addition, Fe2O3 also showed good stability in the photocatalysis processes (Mishra and Chun, 2015). The surface reactions of Fe2O3 with PMS produce sulfate radicals through the following reactions (Ji et al., 2013; Oh et al., 2015):
≡Fe3þ OHþ HSO 5/≡Fe3þ SO 5 þ H2O (2)
≡Fe3þ SO 5 þ H2O/SO 5 þ ≡Fe2þ OHþHþ (3)
≡Fe2þ OHþHSO 5/≡Fe2þ SO 5 þ H2O (4)
≡Fe2þ SO 5 þ H2O/SO 4 þ ≡Fe3þ OHþ OH (5)
In fact, the surface reaction of ≡Fe3þ with PMS produces SO5
and ≡Fe2þ; in the next step, ≡Fe2þ reacts with PMS to generate sulfate radical. Although Fe2O3 has been widely used for catalyzing H2O2, its performance in decomposing PMS has been seldom considered (Ji et al., 2013). The comparison of heterogeneous and homogeneous Fe (III) has been rarely reported in the literature. The catalytic activity of Fe2O3 for the activation of other oxidants has not been considered. In addition, photocatalytic activity of Fe2O3 in the presence of PMS has not been performed yet. To the best of our knowledge, no study has been reported on 2,4-D degradation by Fe2O3/PMS with focus on the mechanism in detail. Based on the abovementioned descriptions, in this work, Fe2O3 (hematite) nanoparticles (HNPs) were prepared and their catalytic activity was tested for PMS activation to degrade 2,4-D. The effects of main operating parameters and some anions were evaluated for degrading 2,4-D in the PMS/HNPs system. Ferric and ferrous ions as the homogeneous activators were also tested for comparison with HNPs. HNPs were tested for activating other oxidants to compare with PMS. Finally, the PMS/Fe2O3 system was assessed in the presence of UV irradiation and its mechanism was described.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and reagents
sections.text: 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (C8H6Cl2O3) was purchased from Merck company with a purity of >98%. Peroxymonosulfate was provided by Aldrich Inc. in the form of Oxone salt (KHSO5$0.5KHSO4$0.5K2SO4). FeCl3.6H2O, silver nitrate, urea, and potassium chromate were purchased from Merck Company. Ethanol and tert-butyl alcohol were provided by Alfa Aesar and Sigma-Aldrich, respectively. Acetonitrile and pure water with HPLC grade were provided by Samchun Company. Sodium persulfate was purchased from Fluka Inc. Sodium percarbonate (2Na2CO3$3H2O2) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Company. Ferric sulfate (Fe2(SO4)3) (Fisher Scientific Inc.) and ferrous sulfate (Fe2SO4) (Merck Inc.) were used for the homogeneous system. Sodium chloride (NaCl), sodium nitrate (NaNO3), and sodium hydrogen phosphate (Na2HPO4) were purchased from ChemLab Company.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of Fe2O3 nanoparticles and their characteristics
sections.text:
Fe2O3 was synthesized by the hydro-thermal method. In this method, 2.20 g FeCl3$6H2O and 2.0 g urea were added to 50 mL distilled water. A total of 25mL of ammonium hydroxidewas added dropwise into the solution with continuous magnetic stirring. The solution was poured into a Teflon-lined container, and it was then heated at 150 C for 12 h. The solution was cooled under room temperature. The obtained precipitates were washed by ethanol and distilled water for three times. Finally, the precipitates were calcinated at 450 C for 3 h (Gobouri, 2016; Tadic et al., 2014). The morphology and particle size were analyzed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) (Mira 3-Xmu). A Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra was used for the determination of bond group in HNPs which was recorded using a Vertex 70 spectrophotometer (Bruker, Germany) with a resolution of 2 cm 1. The crystallographic structure of HNPs was studied by X-ray diffraction
(XRD) analysis, which was recorded by a D8 Bruker advanced diffractometer with Cu-Ka radiation. The size of particle was also analyzed by a particle size analyzer (Scatterscope I model, Quidix Inc). The BrunauereEmmetteTeller (BET) specific surface area and pore volume were obtained by measuring the N2 adsorption/ desorptionwith a Beckman Coulter 3100. The pore size distribution was calculated using the BJH (BarretteJoynereHalenda) method.

sections.heading: 2.3. 2,4-D degradation by PMS/HNPs
sections.text: The experiments were conducted in 0.2 L of 2,4-D solution in flasks shaken at 300 rpm. All experiments were conducted at 25e27 C. The solution pH was adjusted by sulfuric acid (0.1 N) and sodium hydroxide (0.1 M). A desired amount of HNPs was added to the solution, and a certain amount of PMS was then immediately added to the solution. 5 mL aliquots of the solution were taken at preselected reaction intervals; they were then filtrated by a 0.2-mm PTFE syringe filter for 2,4-D analysis. The reusability of the catalyst was evaluated by repetitive experiments at the same condition. The mixture of the catalyst and the solutionwas centrifuged to separate Fe2O3 from the liquid phase after reaction time, and the obtained catalyst was washed for three times.

sections.heading: 2.4. Analytical methods
sections.text: 2,4-D was measured by a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (KNAUER, Germany) with a 2500 ultraviolet (UV) detector. The detectionwavelength of 2,4-Dwas 280 nm. A C8 (100- 5) column (250 mm 4.6 mm, with 5 mm particle size) was employed for the separation as the stationary phase. The isocratic mobile phase consisted of acetonitrile and water with a ratio of 1:1 and its flow rate was 0.5 mL/min. The injection volume was 20 mL, which was manually injected, while the column temperature was set at 30 C. The analysis time was equal to 10.0 min and retention time for 2,4-D was 3.4 min. Ten levels of 2,4-D (0.001e50.0 mg/L) were considered for the calibration curve. The R-squared for the obtained calibration curve was 0.9999. Chloride ion was determined by the titration method using silver nitrate. Total organic carbon (TOC) value was analyzed by a TOC analyzer (Shimadzu). Chemical oxygen demand (COD) was measured by the colorimetric method at 400 nm using a spectrophotometer (DR5000, HACH) (APHA, 1999). The iron concentrations weremeasured by an atomic absorption spectrometer (Analytik Jena, Vario 6).

sections.heading: 3.1. Characteristics of HNPs
sections.text:
Fig. 1a and b shows the morphology of HNPs by the FESEM image in two different scales. Fig. 1a clearly depicts the mesoporous arrangement of the inner structure of HNPs. Fig. 1b illustrates the distribution of HNPs in which the homogeneity of HNPs was obvious. Moreover, this figure demonstrated the uniformity of size of particles in the obtained HNPs, which were in range of 30e60 nm. Fig. 1c depicted the XRD pattern of synthesized HNPs. As observed, all the obtained peaks can be assigned to the pure hematite phase (JCPDS ID: 330664) of iron oxide. The main diffractions were (012), (104), (110), (112), (113), (024), (116), (018), (214), and (300). No impurities were observed based on the XRD pattern. The average crystal size (D) for HNPs was calculated based on Debye Scherrer's equation, D¼ 0.89l/bcosq, where l is the X-ray wavelength (1.540598 Å), b is the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of diffraction line which is expressed in radians and q is the diffraction angle of the XRD spectra. The obtained average crystal size of HNPs was around 45.7 nm, confirming the results of
FESEM analysis. Fig. 1d shows the FTIR analysis of HNPs. Two peaks at 447 and 529 cm 1 were observed, which were related to Fe-O group; this is in agreement with the synthesis of Fe2O3. The results of PSA revealed that d50 and d100 were 37.2 nm and 54.9 nm, respectively, which were in agreement with the other obtained results. Fig. 1e depicts N2 adsorptionedesorption isotherms of HNPs and the pore size distribution. The calculated BET surface area, average pore size, and pore volume were 24.76 m2/g, 13.7 nm, and 0.2751 cm3/g, respectively. These results showed that HNPs had a typical mesoporous structure.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effects of solution pH, HNPs, and PMS dosages
sections.text:
The effect of solution pH was investigated in the range of 3.0e10.0 under the condition of 2 mM PMS, 0.3 g/L HNPs, and 60min reaction time (Fig. 2a). As observed, the acidic condition (pH 3.0e6.0) showed high efficiency for 2,4-D degradation. These results are obtained from the positive charge of HNPs surface adsorbing anionic form of 2,4-D in acidic pH. Hence, activated PMS degraded 2,4-D on the surface of HNPs. On the other hand, degradation of 2,4-D was decreased by the increase in pH values which was related to the nonradical decomposition of PMS at the alkaline condition as pka2 for PMS is 9.4 in which its dominant form is SO52in alkaline pH (Wang and Chu, 2011). It should be noted that free radicals as the responsible agents have higher oxidation potentials in the acidic condition and they are also rather stable in the acidic condition (Huang et al., 2009). The results suggest that a pH value of 6 was suitable since it was near the neutral condition which was similar to the pH of the agricultural wastewaters.
Fig. 2b showed that the increase in HNPs dosage enhanced the 2,4-D removal efficiency significantly. As observed, the application of PMS alone was almost ineffective in 2,4-D removal indicating that PMS should be activated for the degradation of organic compounds and its oxidative potential is insufficient to break down the 2,4-D molecule. Adding only 0.05 g/L of HNPs improved the performance of the system and further increase of the catalyst raised the removal efficiency. This enhancement in the system efficiency is related to the increase in the Fe content in higher dosage of HNPs. In this process 2,4-D removals were 22.6, 51.3, 64.8, 70.8, and 71.9% for 0.05, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, and 0.7 g/L HNPs, respectively. After 0.5 g/L HNPs, no significant improvement was observed revealing that increasing the HNPs dosage was effective up to a certain amount.
The effect of PMS dosage was evaluated under the conditions of 0.5 g/L HNPs and pH of 6.0 (Fig. 2c). As observed, in the absence of PMS, 2,4-D adsorption on HNPs was almost low (13.3%) implying that sole application of HNPs for 2,4-D removal was inefficient. On the other hand, the degradation rate of 2,4-D dramatically increased with the increase in PMS dosage. 2,4-D removals were 20.8, 57.3, 70.8, 79.8, and 79.1% for PMS dosages of 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0 mM, respectively. Increasing PMS concentration consequently increased the amount of sulfate radical resulting in more degradation of 2,4-D. This influence has been often observed in the chemical oxidation processes especially in Fenton process. However, 2,4-D removal was slightly decreased in the highest PMS dosage (4 mM). This phenomenon was related to overdosing the PMS which can scavenge sulfate radical according to Equation (6) (Chen et al., 2007; Rivas et al., 2012).
HSO 5 þ SO 4 /SO 2 4 þ SO 5 þ Hþ (6)
In addition to chemical oxidant and activator dosages, initial 2,4-D concentration was an important factor as well. 2,4-D concentrations in the range of 5.0e50 mg/L were studied when PMS and HNPs dosages were kept constant. As shown in Fig. 3a, the degradation rate of 2,4-D was reduced in higher concentration of
2,4-D which was attributed to the lack of sufficient free radicals for 2,4-D degradation. 2,4-D was completely removed in 40 min reaction time for an initial concentration of 5 mg/L, while 52% of 50 mg/L was degraded during 60 min reaction time. In the heterogeneous catalyst system, the 2,4-D degradation occurs at the surface of HNPs by sulfate radicals produced on the active sites of HNPs. In high concentration of 2,4-D, a competitive reaction for adsorption of 2,4-D and PMS activation may occur on the active sites of HNPs which can limit the degradation of 2,4-D. In order to
determine the degradation rate constant of 2,4-D by PMS/HNPs, the first-order kinetic model was fitted based on Equation (7).
Ln ½2;4 D ½2;4 D 0 ¼ kobst (7)
where kobs is the observed first-order rate constant (min 1) and t is reaction time (min). The plot of Ln([2,4-D]/[2,4-D]0) versus t was well fitted for 2,4-D degradation, as shown in Fig. S1, supporting
Fig. 3. (a) the effect of initial concentration of 2,4-D and kinetic study (pH ¼ 6.0, PMS ¼ 3.0 using the L-H model.
information (SI). The slope of the straight line for the plot determines the kobs values which are presented in Tables S2 and SI. The results showed that the first-order model with R2 ¼ > 0.95 was the favorable model for the description of 2,4-D degradation by PMS/HNPs. Besides the LangmuireHinshelwood (L-H) model has been broadly used to explain the heterogeneous catalytic reactions in AOPs. In the current study, the L-H model was applied to determine whether the surface reactions influenced 2,4-D degradation based on Equations (8) and (9).
kobs ¼ kcKS
1þ kc½2;4 D 0 (8)
and linear expression
1 kobs ¼ 1 kc ½2;4 D 0 þ 1 kcKS
(9)
where kc and KS are the intrinsic surface reaction rate constant (mg/ L.min) and LangmuireHinshelwood adsorption equilibrium constant (L/mg), respectively. The values of kc and KS are calculated by plotting the 1/kobs against the initial concentrations of 2,4-D. The plot of 1/kobs versus 2,4-D0 is presented in Fig. 3b. It is observed that the L-M model was fitted with excellent R2 ¼ 0.994 indicating that HNPs surface plays a critical role in sorption and oxidation of 2,4-D. The obtained kc and KS were 0.70 mg/L.min and 0.247 L/mg, respectively. According to the obtained results from adsorption tests (Fig. S3), there was a competitive adsorption between 2,4-D and PMS onto the active sites during the reaction because the Ks valuewas lower than the adsorption constant (K¼ 11.5 L/mg) in the absence of PMS (Zubir et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 3.3. Comparison with homogeneous system and evaluation of stability
sections.text:
A series of experiments was conducted by ferrous and ferric ions in the presence of PMS for comparisonwith HNPs. Fig. 4a illustrates the performances of three systems in 2,4-D removal at the same condition. The PMS/HNPs system degraded around 80% of 2,4-D during 60 min reaction time, whereas Fe2þ/PMS and Fe3þ/PMS removed 40% and 50% of 2,4-D at the same reaction time, respectively. Besides the preferable efficiency of HNPs, it is observed that the trend of the heterogeneous system was different compared to the homogeneous system. In the heterogeneous system, the catalytic activity continuously increased during 60 min while in
mM, 0.5 g/L HNPs); (b) relationship between the 1/kobs and initial 2,4-D concentrations
homogeneous catalyst, a steady-state situation was observed after 20 min reaction time. These results showed that the degradation rate was high during first 20 min in homogeneous catalyst, following which the degradation ratewas significantly reduced due to the slow regeneration of the catalyst. The precipitation of iron species in pH ¼ 6.0 can be the main reason for low efficiency in the homogeneous catalyst (Tan et al., 2012; Wang and Chu, 2011). In this manner, the homogenous systems of PMS/Fe2þ and PMS/Fe3þ were tested in various pH values (Figs. S4 and SI). As observed, neutral and alkaline conditions were ineffective for the homogeneous systems because of the abovementioned reason. Accordingly, it can be concluded that the heterogeneous catalyst was not influenced by pH changes compared to the iron-based homogeneous catalyst.
The stability of HNPs was assessed for five consecutive cycles under the conditions of 20 mg/L 2,4-D, pH ¼ 6.0, 3 mM PMS, and 0.5 g/L HNPs. After each experiment, HNPs were separated by a centrifuge and then washed only by deionized water for three times. Fig. 4b depicts the 2,4-D removals for five consecutive runs. As observed, the 2,4-D removal efficiency gradually decreased during five runs. The fresh catalyst provided around 80% removal efficiency and this value reached 57% after the fifth run. The main reason for this decrease can be attributed to the deterioration of the active catalytic sites, which are the main responsible agents of activating PMS. On the other hand, contamination of the catalyst surface might have occurred by adsorption of organic compounds and intermediates, leading to a decrease in catalytic activity (Qi et al., 2013). This phenomenon showed that water washing was not enough for cleaning the HNPs surface. However, HNPs exhibited a relatively good stability for reuse in several runs without any
Fig. 5. (a) the effect of different oxidants on 2,4-D removal in HNPs/oxidant (b) the concentration ¼ 3.0 mM, pH ¼ 6.0, HNPs ¼ 0.5 g/L, time ¼ 60 min).
significant drop in catalytic activity. The leaching iron was monitored during five cycles in which the concentrations of iron were <0.02, 0.22, 0.50, 0.59, and 0.8 mg/L for the first, second, third, fourth, and fifth use of HNPs, respectively. According to the results, with increasing the number of HNPs-using cycles, the leaching iron concentration was increased. With respect to this fact that 0.5 g HNPs contained 0.35 g iron and maximum leaching iron concentration was 0.8 mg/L (0.22%), iron loss in HNPs could not have influenced the decrease in activity. Likewise, iron species (Fe (II)/Fe (III)) were identified during reaction time (Figs. S5 and SI). According to the obtained results, although leached iron concentration was low in the solution, the simultaneous presence of ferrous and ferric ions and changes in Fe (II) and Fe (III) concentrations indicated that PMS was in reaction with both species.

sections.heading: 3.4. Comparison with other oxidants and the effects of anions
sections.text:
Catalytic activity of HNPs was also investigated by other oxidants, including persulfate (S2O82 ), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and percarbonate (2Na2CO3$3H2O2). Fig. 5a displays activation of the oxidants in the presence of HNPs for 2,4-D removal. As observed, PMS and persulfate had almost similar results. However PMS was slightly superior compared to persulfate in terms of 2,4-D removal. Conversely, activated hydrogen peroxide and percarbonate degraded 41.2% and 32.9% of 2,4-D, respectively. Two outcomes can be understood from these results. First, HNPs were more successful in the activation of sulfate-based oxidants (PMS and persulfate) compared to other ones. Second, the tendency of 2,4-D for reaction with sulfate radical in PMS and persulfate systems was more than that with hydroxyl radical in H2O2 and percarbonate systems. This
effect of the anions (3 mM) on 2,4-D removal in the PMS/HNPs system (oxidant
behavior is likely because of selectivity characteristic of sulfate radical for reaction with organic compounds (Hu and Long, 2016; Oh et al., 2016). In fact, PMS could be activated easily compared to other oxidants thanks to its asymmetrical structure. In terms of percarbonate, it should be noted that the presence of carbonate ions in percarbonate (2Na2CO3$3H2O2) can suppress hydroxyl radical-based degradation through reaction of carbonate with hydroxyl radical and production of carbonate radical with less reactivity as a consequence (Equation (10)).
CO 23 þ HO /CO 3 þHO (10)
Furthermore, since the efficiency of the oxidants was evaluated at pH ¼ 6.0, it can be concluded that the sulfate radical-based processes (persulfate and PMS) had a superiority in terms of application in wide range of pH compared to hydroxyl radicalbased processes (H2O2 and percarbonate). Besides it should be noted that the oxidation potential of hydroxyl radicals is low in neutral and alkaline conditions compared to the acidic condition (Akbari et al., 2016; Hu and Long, 2016).
Most anions can affect the performance of sulfate radical-based processes. Hence, the presence of these anions in natural aquatic environment should be avoided. The effects of chloride (Cl ), nitrate (NO3 ), and hydrogen phosphate (HPO42 ) were investigated in the PMS/HNPs system and their results are presented in Fig. 5b. As shown, the presence of the anions reduced the performance of PMS/HNPs system. In this process, the order of inhibitory effect of the anions was Cl > NO3 > HPO42 . In the literature, chloride ion is known as a scavenger of free radicals based on Equation (11) (Yuan et al., 2011). Chloride radical is produced through a reaction between sulfate radical and chloride ion which has lower oxidation potential in comparison with sulfate radical. Indeed, chloride ions compete with organic compounds for a reaction with sulfate radical. Hence, in the presence of chloride, the degradation of 2,4-D was significantly decreased (Ji et al., 2015; Tay et al., 2013).
SO 4 þ Cl /SO2 4 þ Cl
(11)
Cl þ Cl /Cl 2 (12)
Cl 2 þ Cl 2 /2Cl þ Cl2 (13)
Cl þ Cl /Cl2 (14) Chloride ion can directly react with PMS to produce sulfate ions (Equations (15) and (16)). Actually, PMS decomposition occurs in a nonradical pathway and a decrease in 2,4-D degradation was observed as a consequence (Chan and Chu, 2009;Wang et al., 2011).
Cl þHSO 5/SO2 4 þHOCl (15)
2Cl þ HSO 5 þ Hþ/SO2 4 þ Cl2 þ H2O (16) In terms of nitrate and hydrogen phosphate, scavenging effects of anions were observed. Nitrate and hydrogen phosphate ions scavenge sulfate radical and produce nitrate radical and hydrogen phosphate radical through electron transfer mechanism. However, nitrate and hydrogen phosphate played aminor role in the decrease of efficiency in comparison with chloride.

sections.heading: 3.5. The effect of presence of UV irradiation
sections.text:
HNPs have exhibited photocatalytic behavior for degradation of organic compounds. For this purpose, a series of experiments were
conducted using four UVA lamps (6-Watt, Phillips) in a quartz reactor with a capacity of 0.26 L for 0.2 L 2,4-D solution similar to the previous steps. Fig. 6a displays the effect of presence of UV on 2,4-D removal in the PMS/HNPs system. As observed, the presence of UV in the PMS/HNPs system increased the degradation rate of 2,4-D in a way that 90.2% of 2,4-D was eliminated compared to 79.8% degradation in the absence of UV. In other words, the rate constant of 2,4-D degradation was increased from 0.0267 min 1 to 0.041 min 1 in the presence of UV. This improvement in degradation of 2,4-D can be related to two mechanisms. First, the production of hydroxyl radical by the excitation of HNPs through which the obtained hole reacts with water molecules according to Equations (17) and (18). Second, electron conduction can decompose PMS in the radical pathway and produce sulfate or hydroxyl radicals based on Equation (19). Hence, the photocatalytic behavior of HNPs not only influences 2,4-D degradation but also can activate PMS for more production of free radicals (Ahmadi et al., 2015; Zhu et al., 2016).
F2O3 þ hv/e CB þ hþ (17)
hþ þH2O/HO þ Hþ (18)
HSO 5 þ e CB/OH þ SO 4 or HO þ SO2 4 (19) In confirming of photocatalytic behavior of HNPs, UVA/HNPs without PMS could degrade around 45% of 2,4-D during 60 min irradiation time. The results suggest that UVA was impotent in the activation of PMS because PMS in the presence of UV could provide only 10% removal efficiency. The mechanism of degradation of 2,4- D by the dual role of Fe2O3 for PMS activation is presented in Fig. 6b.
It is important to note that the recovery of HNPs at the industrial scale faces some difficulties since sedimentation and filtration are ineffective for the separation of nanoparticles. In order to overcome the limitation of recovery of HNPs, three strategies can be considered. First, HNPs are synthesized in the form of thin film especially for combining with UV. Second, HNPs are immobilized on a porous support in a packed bed catalytic reactor. Third, the use of catalytic membrane decorated with HNPs which has bilateral mechanisms of oxidation and filtration.

sections.heading: 3.6. Mineralization study and quenching experiments
sections.text:
To determine the degradation of organic matter, COD and TOC removals and chloride ion releasewere studied under the condition of 50 mg/L 2,4-D, PMS¼ 3.0 mM, 0.5 g/L HNPs, and a solution pH of 6.0 and their results are depicted in Fig. 7a. As observed, 32.1% of COD and 26.5% of TOC were removed after 60 min reaction time while 2,4-D removal was 52.3% at the same conditions. During the reaction of sulfate radical with 2,4-D, chlorine might have been separated in the form of chloride ion. Thus, chloride ion was monitored during the reaction time. The chloride ion concentration was increased by the increase in reaction time and it reached 4.7 mg/L at 45 min reaction time. This value is approximately 29.7% of total chlorine content of 2,4-D (15.8 mg Cl/L). After 45 min reaction time, the concentration of chloride ion was dropped to 3.8 mg/L. This decrease was presumably because of the reaction of chloride with PMS based on Equations (15) and (16). It is
worthwhile to express that an increase in the dechlorination of aromatic compounds implies the decrease in the toxicity of chlorinated organics.
With the purpose of determining the responsible agent of 2,4-D degradation a quenching experiment was conducted by two alcohols of ethanol and tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) with 100 mM concentration. Ethanol scavenges the sulfate and hydroxyl radicals with high rate constants (7.7 107 M 1s 1for SO4 and 2.8 109 M 1s 1 for HO ). Whereas TBA is a specific scavenger for HO with a rate constant of 7.6 108 M 1s 1 its rate constant with sulfate radical is 4 105 M 1s 1 (1000 times less than hydroxyl radical) (Lin et al., 2014; Zeng et al., 2015). Hence, in the presence of TBA obtained degradation is related to sulfate radical. As shown in Fig. 7b, in the absence of the scavengers, around 80% of 2,4-D was eliminated while in the presence of ethanol, 2,4-D degradationwas substantially reduced to only 9% indicating that the radicals mainly contributed in the degradation of 2,4-D. In the presence of TBA, 2,4- D removal efficiency was 64.3% during 60 min reaction time. In comparison with the control condition, a slight decrease was observed in the presence of TBA revealing that 2,4-D degradation was substantially corresponded to sulfate radicals. Hence, sulfate radical was the main performer in the oxidation of 2,4-D based on quenching results.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, the performance of HNPs for the activation of PMS was investigated for degrading 2,4-D. 2,4-D degradation was more successful in the acidic condition in PMS/HNPs. Moreover, a scavenging effect was observed at higher concentration of PMS. Around 80% of 2,4-D was removed at pH ¼ 6.0, PMS ¼ 3 mM, HNPs ¼ 0.5 g/ L, and reaction time of 60 min inwhich the first-order rate constant was found to be 0.0267 min 1. HNPs exhibited a better performance in comparison with homogeneous iron forms. Apart from that, HNPs were also reusable in at least four cycling runs. The presence of chloride ion significantly reduced 2,4-D degradation. Catalytic activity of HNPs for sulfate-based oxidant (persulfate and PMS) was better than that for H2O2 and percarbonate. The presence of UV irradiation improved the performance of PMS/HNPs in 2,4-D degradation. However, the PMS/HNPs weakly mineralized 2,4-D in terms of COD and TOC removals. The quenching study clearly revealed that sulfate radical was the main contributor in 2,4-D elimination.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work was a part of a funded Ph.D. thesis of Farshid Ghanbari, Ahvaz Jundishapur University of Medical Sciences (AJUMS), and the financial support of this study (ETRC-9432) was provided by AJUMS.

referenceMentions.context: 2,4Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) is a conventional herbicide that has been widely used in agricultural farms to control the weeds (Tang et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2009).
2,4Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) is a conventional herbicide that has been widely used in agricultural farms to control the weeds (Tang et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2009).
Over 600 commercial types of 2,4-D are produced in market for the control of weeds (Matviishyn et al., 2014; Taktak et al., 2015).
Its stability and toxicity have caused increased use of advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) for its degradation (Kamble et al., 2004).
There are several techniques used for generating the hydroxyl radical, including chemical, photochemical, sonochemical, and electrochemical processes (Asghar et al., 2015;Mahamuni and Adewuyi, 2010).
1 V, which is generated by the activation of persulfate or peroxymonosulfate (PMS) anions (Jaafarzadeh et al., 2016).
Peroxymonosulfate is a benign substance, and it can be activated by different methods to produce the sulfate radicals (Ghanbari and Moradi, 2017; Guan et al., 2013).
Peroxymonosulfate is a benign substance, and it can be activated by different methods to produce the sulfate radicals (Ghanbari and Moradi, 2017; Guan et al., 2013).
These methods include the use of transition metals (Anipsitakis and Dionysiou, 2003), ultraviolet (Jaafarzadeh et al.
These methods include the use of transition metals (Anipsitakis and Dionysiou, 2003), ultraviolet (Jaafarzadeh et al., 2015), ultrasound (Su et al.
, 2015), ultrasound (Su et al., 2012), heat (Yang et al.
, 2012), heat (Yang et al., 2010), and carbon-based catalyst (Ghanbari et al.
, 2010), and carbon-based catalyst (Ghanbari et al., 2016).
Moreover, the heterogeneous catalyst can maintain its activity after repeated use, which is a significant advantage compared to the homogeneous form (Zhu et al., 2013).
The hematite (Fe2O3) or iron oxide (III) has been widely used in photocatalysis and Fenton-based processes as the catalyst (Guo et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2016; Mishra and Chun, 2015).
The hematite (Fe2O3) or iron oxide (III) has been widely used in photocatalysis and Fenton-based processes as the catalyst (Guo et al., 2010; Huang et al., 2016; Mishra and Chun, 2015).

Although Fe2O3 has been widely used for catalyzing H2O2, its performance in decomposing PMS has been seldom considered (Ji et al., 2013).

It should be noted that free radicals as the responsible agents have higher oxidation potentials in the acidic condition and they are also rather stable in the acidic condition (Huang et al., 2009).
This phenomenon was related to overdosing the PMS which can scavenge sulfate radical according to Equation (6) (Chen et al., 2007; Rivas et al., 2012).

Besides it should be noted that the oxidation potential of hydroxyl radicals is low in neutral and alkaline conditions compared to the acidic condition (Akbari et al., 2016; Hu and Long, 2016).
Besides it should be noted that the oxidation potential of hydroxyl radicals is low in neutral and alkaline conditions compared to the acidic condition (Akbari et al., 2016; Hu and Long, 2016).
In the literature, chloride ion is known as a scavenger of free radicals based on Equation (11) (Yuan et al., 2011).
Hence, in the presence of chloride, the degradation of 2,4-D was significantly decreased (Ji et al., 2015; Tay et al., 2013).
Hence, in the presence of chloride, the degradation of 2,4-D was significantly decreased (Ji et al., 2015; Tay et al., 2013).
Actually, PMS decomposition occurs in a nonradical pathway and a decrease in 2,4-D degradation was observed as a consequence (Chan and Chu, 2009;Wang et al., 2011).
Actually, PMS decomposition occurs in a nonradical pathway and a decrease in 2,4-D degradation was observed as a consequence (Chan and Chu, 2009;Wang et al., 2011).
Hence, the photocatalytic behavior of HNPs not only influences 2,4-D degradation but also can activate PMS for more production of free radicals (Ahmadi et al., 2015; Zhu et al., 2016).
